options: Advise Ashley to contact occupational health
Advise Ashley to request for compassionate leave
Advise Ashley to discuss this with her educational supervisor
Offer reassurance to Ashley and listen to her concerns
Inform Ashley's clinical supervisor of her concerns
Offer to assist Ashley with some of her workload
Suggest to Ashley to take Zopiclone to aid sleeping
Inform your F2 colleagues of Ashley's situation and seek them to help her by covering her weekend shift so that she can have some time off
questions:
You are chatting with your F2 colleague, Ashley during your break. She tells you that her father has been diagnosed with late stages of prostate cancer with lung metastases. She is very stressed and couldn't sleep at night. She thinks that she is going to have difficulty coping at work. However, she is hesitant to speak to a senior about this as she does not want this to affect her successfully completing her training programme.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
B is correct as it is reasonable to request compassionate leave if you are dealing with family matters that might affect your working shifts or ability to work safely. Annual leave or medical leave will be inappropriate.

C is correct. By advising her to approach her educational supervisor herself, they may be able to provide more appropriate support or help that she may needs

D is correct. It is always helpful to listen and give moral support to your fellow colleague. Even though you might not be able to help her, it will be good to lend a listening ear.

A is incorrect as occupational health would not be able to help her with family matters.

E is incorrect as it is inappropriate to inform her clinical supervisor without her permission, you should advise her to speak to her clinical supervisor instead.

G is incorrect as it is wrong and unsafe for someone to take zopiclone without getting a proper assessment. She should see her GP if she needs any help with sleeping or any kind of support.

F and H is incorrect. Even though you are helping her by reducing her workload, it will be unfair to you and your fellow colleagues. They should not be asked to bear additional responsibility which may lead to unsafe practice. Moreover, this solution is not feasible in long run too.

title: GMC: Leadership and management for all doctors - Working with colleagues
body:
As with all aspects of medicine, the fundamental principle remains the same; make the patient your first concern. The purpose of this guidance is to allow the effective functioning of the clinical team to allow patient care to be done safely and smoothly, to the highest standards.

Leadership

The recommendations on leadership emphasise the importance of working within a multidisciplinary team. They specifically mention that other team members in leadership positions must be respected. This respect for non-medical staff in leadership roles is important.

For example, respecting the advice and leadership of an infection control nurse with regard to hand hygiene is important in making patients are protected from iatrogenic pathogen spread.

Respect for colleagues

If a colleague feels like they are not respected and not valued they may not feel able to speak up if they have concerns which may be relevant to patient safety. This is particularly important for junior and non-medical staff, and so it especially important to respect and value their skills and contribution to the team.

Additionally there is both a legal and moral responsibility to ensure that your colleagues have a safe and fair workplace. All doctors are responsible for facilitating this not only to avoid unpleasant behaviour themselves, but also by challenging others who act in a bullying or discriminatory manner. This is important both to comply with laws and policies on equality and diversity, but also to ensure patient safety as bullying and harassment will impair team cohesion and communication.


Communication within and between teams

The key message from this part of the guidance is that it is important that it is clear who is responsible for communicating what information both within members of the team, to other teams, and also to patients and carers. Mistakes are often made when team members assume that someone else will have passed on the relevant information and no one ends up doing it. Therefore whenever there is any doubt about whose job it is to pass on certain information, it is obligatory to check.

For example, if you expect that the nursing staff would have told you about any allergies the patient has, before prescribing it would be important to confirm with them that they have handed over all the relevant information.

Also it is important that teams cooperate more generally, including by having handovers. Proactive steps must be taken to clarify responsibilities and improve communication.

Responsibility and accountability

The most important duty of a doctor is to the dignity, safety and care of their patients. Again, it is important for doctors to ensure that it is clear exactly which staff members have which responsibilities, to ensure that these do not 'fall between the cracks' and get missed.

It is also important that you make these responsibilities clear to any staff in a team that you are leading.

When mistakes happen, it's often the result of system problems. For example it could be under-staffing putting decision making under higher strain, causing more mistakes. This happened in the Bawa-Garba case, the tragic death of a child from unrecognised sepsis on a day where a single doctor was trying to cover multiple wards.

Consequently, it is also the responsibility of doctors to engage in setting up and maintaining systems to make sure that risks are appropriately assessed and managed. Doctors are just as accountable for advice they give as a member of a decision making body, as they are for any other medical advice they offer.

options: Use Google translate to communicate
Gain consent from the patient and request that a doctor colleague who speaks Polish communicates with the patient
Ask your registrar for advice on how to proceed
Gain consent from the patient and ring the NHS languages service to obtain a translator
Gain consent from the patient and ask another Polish patient in the waiting area to act as translator
questions:
You are a junior doctor in the emergency department. A patient arrives by ambulance who is in considerable abdominal pain that appears characteristic of appendicitis. On speaking to the ambulance staff you become aware that the patient is Polish and does not speak much English.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in this scenario are those of communication, confidentiality and patient safety.

Being able to effectively communicate with patients is a vital component of good medical care, with different languages sometimes being a barrier to that. This is an emergency situation and a method of translation is required. Before doing so, however, it is necessary to try and explain to the patient that you are going to obtain a translator and attempt to gain consent for this if possible. Asking a doctor colleague who speaks Polish to communicate with the patient (B) is the best course of action. This would be faster than obtaining an NHS translator (D).

Asking your registrar for advice on how to proceed (C) would only result in him telling you to obtain a translator, so is an option that doesn't particularly progress your management of this situation. However, it is better than the last two options.

Using Google Translate (A) is a poor option - using such a service may increase the risk of a miscommunication which could affect patient safety.

Asking another Polish patient in the waiting area to act as a translator (E) is a breach of your patient's confidentiality and privacy, making this an unnacceptable and inappropriate response.

options: Phone the Vascular Specialist Nurse to get more information about their protocols
Phone the Vascular Specialist Nurse and tell her that she must fit the compression stockings as the consultant has overall responsibility for the patient
Phone your consultant to discuss the situation
Fit the compression stockings yourself and make a formal complaint using the hospital's complaint system
Phone the Vascular Specialist Trainee on-call and ask him to speak to the Vascular Specialist Nurse on your behalf
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in medicine. On your ward there is an elderly lady with chronic leg ulcers. Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) measurements are taken following which your consultant asks for compression stockings to be fitted. A referral is therefore made to the Vascular Specialist Nurse. A few days later you get a phone call from the nurse who says she is not happy to fit compression stockings on this particular patient due to low ABPI readings.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
From a clinical perspective, fitting compression stockings on a patient with a low ABPI may be harmful as it would further reduce perfusion to the lower leg.

Most Specialist Nurses work within defined parameters and it is therefore the best option to first find out what their protocol is regarding compression stockings. It may be that your consultant simply wasn't aware of the criteria.

The next best response is to discuss the situation with your consultant so he/she may make a decision about the best course of action.

Speaking to the Vascular Specialist Trainee may be useful as they will probably support the opinion of the nurse. However, trying to use the Vascular Specialist Trainee to persuade or pressure the nurse into changing her mind is wrong and unlikely to be successful. From a practical point of view remember that senior doctors such as registrars and consultants often have very close working relationships with specialist nurses.

Ordering the nurse to do something she feels is harmful to the patient is clearly wrong and unlikely to be successful.

You are unlikely to be trained in fitting compression stockings and would be doing so against the advice of an experienced practitioner. This is therefore the worst option.

options: Remove him from the practice list if he refuses to give up smoking
Alter his inhaler treatment and raise it at the practice meeting
Alter his inhaler treatment and speak to the doctor concerned
Refuse to alter his inhaler treatment until he has agreed to be referred to smoking cessation
Alter his inhaler treatment and advise the patient to see you next time
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in General Practice. You see a 29-year-old man with asthma. He tells you he has come to see you today because one of the partners refuses to alter his inhaler therapy until he gives up smoking. He is currently using a salbutamol inhaler as required but is now having frequent episodes of wheeze and he has developed a nocturnal cough.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Although continuing to smoke is clearly going to make his asthma control worse it is not a reason to withhold treatment from a patient. After being made aware of this you have duty to follow it up with the doctor concerned. This also allows the doctor to explain the consultation from his/her point of view. Raising this at the practice meeting is less ideal as it may appear confrontational.

Altering his inhaler treatment alone fails to address the issue of treatment being withheld. Refusing to alter his inhalers until he has agreed to be referred to smoking cessation is basically blackmail and not acceptable. Removing him from the practice list for not giving up smoking again is clearly wrong.

notes:
The General Medical Council offers guidance on prescribing:

In this question you are required to decide which source will guide your prescription. Remember, your prescriptions are your responsibility.

If your prescriptions are ever questioned then it is best to have a respectable and official source. Word of mouth form a junior colleague is not very defendable, whilst from the BNF or pharmacy department is better. Failing that, the advice of a senior is valuable and is a reasonable option.

options: Ask the cardiology registrar if you can send pictures via NHS email instead
Inform the registrar this would be against your hospital policies. Manage the patient to the best of your abilities and handover to the morning team
Seek advice on ECG interpretation from another colleague in your hospital
Send the pictures of the ECG to the registrar via WhatsApp making sure you omit any patient identifiable information
Tell the registrar you will send the pictures via NHS email instead
questions:
You are on the night shift in general medicine when you get bleeped as one of the patients is complaining of palpitations. The nurse performs an ECG. Looking at the trace, you can tell it is not normal, but you are unsure as to what the exact diagnosis is and how to further manage the patient. You phone the cardiology registrar at another hospital, who asks you to send pictures of the ECG via WhatsApp. This is against the policies of your hospital.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
A is the best option. NHS email is a secure means of communication, so you will be able to discuss patient-related matters and solve the situation efficiently.

E achieves the same result, but it is less polite and may be perceived as confrontational. Asking your senior to agree to your suggestion is certainly more appropriate.

C is much less time efficient. Doctors have access to NHS email which is secure and does not breach patient confidentiality. Therefore, this option is less appropriate than the previous two, especially because the scenario is of an acute presentation, therefore time efficiency may be of key importance.

D is a bad option, as it would go against the hospital's policies and risk breaking patient confidentiality.

B is the worst option, as it jeopardises patient safety. In more chronic situations, there would be an argument for this option being higher up on the list, but since this is an acute presentation, B is the most unsafe course of action.

title: GMC: Confidentiality - Using and disclosing patient information for direct care
body:
Sharing patient information is vital for safe and effective care. This is particularly vital when working within multi-disciplinary teams, given that all members must have access to the information that they require for their role. Part of our duty as medical professionals is to ensure that information is only shared in a way that is both legal and ethical, whilst facilitating access to those who require it.

The consequences of inappropriate sharing of information can be significant, for both the clinician/ patient relationship and the wider profession. There have been many media examples of inappropriate information sharing, and being aware of the relevant guidelines is crucial for avoiding this.

General principles:
  • Most patients expect that some information will be shared with those who are directly involved in their care. Unless the patient specifically objects, this is considered implied consent.
  • If a patient objects to particular personal information being shared, you should not disclose the information. The exceptions are: if it is justified for the public interest (as detailed below) or the patient lacks capacity.
  • You should explain to the patient the potential consequences of not allowing personal information to be shared and reach a compromise where possible.
  • In cases where a patient cannot be informed about information sharing, such as an emergency setting, you should pass relevant information to those providing the patient's care.

Naturally, on entry to the hospital, patients may be unable to explicitly state their consent for information sharing. It is therefore easy to forget that they may wish to withhold some details. Wherever possible, it is good practice to discuss with the patient any concerns which they may have. In many cases, these concerns can be rectified without a need to breach confidentiality. This is the ideal scenario, as it helps to maintain transparency between the doctor and patient.

Conditions for sharing information:
  • You must be accessing the information to support the patient's direct care, or be satisfied that it is being shared for that purpose.
  • Patients should be kept informed regarding how their personal information will be used. It should be clear that they have the right to object.
  • You must have no reason to believe the patient has objected to the information being shared.
  • You must be satisfied that anyone you disclose the information to understands that you are giving it to them in confidence.

On a busy ward, there may be times where you are asked to share information about a patient. It is important to always check how this information will be used and to ensure that you are satisfied that it is for the patient's care- for example, sharing information with another department or speciality. Failure to do so could lead to this information falling into the wrong hands. The patient should also be given the opportunity to object to this information being passed further.

Sharing information with friends or relatives:
  • Establish the patient's wishes as early as possible regarding whether they wish to have friends or relatives informed about their care.
  • Do not assume that a patient agrees to the disclosure simply because they have a close relationship with the person who is seeking information. You should gain explicit consent.
  • When a patient lacks capacity, it may be necessary to share some relevant information with friends/ relatives. This does not entitle the person to full access to the patient's clinical records, but can be used to help assess the patient's best interests.

We often assume that a patient will want their family to be involved in their care, and this is often an important feature of palliative and elderly care. Despite this, the patient should still be given their own autonomy over the decision. There may even be exceptions where sharing personal information could put the patient in emotional or physical danger e.g. cases of abuse. Every patient and family is different, and part of the clinician's role is to respect and facilitate this.

If someone close to the patient wants to discuss their concerns about the patient's health/ wellbeing without involving the patient, you should still listen. The information they give you may be helpful in caring for the patient- particularly in cases of mental ill-health. This does not mean that you are obligated to act on the information received, but it may assist in building a clinical picture.

Considerations if a patient lacks capacity:
  • Consider if all possible attempts have been made to explain the disclosure to the patient, using methods and language which they can understand.
  • Consider whether the lack of capacity is temporary or permanent and whether the decision can wait until the patient regains capacity.
  • Consider if the patient has already stated their wishes regarding information being disclosed, in addition to their apparent beliefs and values.
  • Consider if the patient has nominated a person to make health or welfare decisions on their behalf.
  • If a patient asks you not to disclose personal information and you believe they lack the capacity to make this decision, you should try to persuade them to allow an appropriate person to be given relevant information. In some cases, disclosure will be required or necessary e.g. under mental health and mental capacity laws.

When dealing with patients who lack capacity, reflect back to the specific GMC guidance on mental capacity. The main features involve providing the patient with maximal opportunity to state their interests, before making decisions on their behalf. In these cases, also consider if the patient has an appointed person to make decisions on their behalf.

Disclosures by Law

You must not disclose information to a third party without the patient's express consent- unless it is required by law or can be justified in the public interest. It is rare that a disclosure will be required by law, but some examples of these exceptions are detailed below:
  • Following an order made by a judge or presiding officer of a court.
  • In certain cases of communicable disease, when you must inform the local authority.
  • To prevent an act of terrorism.
  • To comply with a statutory request made by a regulatory body such as the GMC.

There are exceptional circumstances where information sharing is not so straight-forward, and one of these relates to gunshot wounds and knife injuries:
  • Gunshot wounds and those caused by a blade/ sharp instrument represent a special category of injury.
  • The police should usually be informed whenever a person presents with a gunshot wound, given the potential risk to others.
  • They should also be informed of most knife injuries- unless the injury appears to be accidental or a result of self-harm.
  • Personal information (such as the patient's name and address) should not be disclosed in the initial contact with the police, and the police will respond even if the patient's identity is not disclosed.

options: Discuss directly with your friend to see if there is an explanation
Stop the family from seeing the child again until they are explained
Call social services
Hand the case over to a senior colleague
Distance yourself from the friend until the case is over
questions:
You are asked to review the chest x-ray of a 4-year-old boy brought into the Emergency Department. The X-ray shows several signs suggestive of old rib fractures. On investigating you can find nothing to explain these injuries in the notes and realise that the child is the nephew of a friend.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes: As this is the child of a friend it would be inappropriate to handle the case yourself regardless of the circumstances, and it should therefore be passed over to a senior colleague who can confirm or deny your interpretation (4). Although not immediately, social services would need to be called in situations such as this (3). Distancing yourself from the friend is not entirely necessary, but details of it should not be discussed under any circumstances (5). Although stopping the family from having access may happen eventually, it may not be until evidence has proven their involvement in these injuries. Until that point they can visit supervised (2). Discussing directly with your friend would breach patient confidentiality, and also place the child at risk of more injury if he is sent home without anyone knowing about the fractures (1).

options: Clerk the patient first
Pop up to the ward and do the small tasks quickly
Politely ask the nurses not to bleep you for the next hour while you are clerking your patient
Ask one of the senior nurses to triage the patient while you eat lunch
Explain to the nurses that these are non-urgent tasks and therefore should wait until the end of the day
Apologise to the nurse and explain that you will do those tasks as soon as you are free
Eat your lunch as soon as you can
Obtain information about the urgency of the incoming patient over the phone
questions:
You are a junior doctor working an on-call shift. You are very busy and have just been asked to clerk a new admission and have not yet had a lunch break. You could be tied up with him for a while once he arrives and it has now passed 3pm. The nurses on the ward are bleeping you to come and rewrite a drug chart and write a discharge letter. You know that both of these tasks could wait until later when you are less busy, however the nursing staff are being very persistent. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
This question is about prioritising tasks. One of the most important things a doctor can do while on-call is to look after themselves. You are no good to patients if you are tired and hungry. By grabbing lunch quickly you will feel better and thus be better prepared to work. Clearly, clerking the patients is more immediately important than going to rewrite a drug chart, however it is still a task which will need doing. In general, nursing staff should understand that you have many people asking things of you during an on-call shift and a simple apology and estimate of a time you will be free to do it is sufficient to keep them happy. Finally, by finding out a bit about your patient before seeing them will enable you to better prioritise how quickly they will need seeing.

By clerking the patient before anything else, you risk delaying your already late lunch break by a lot longer. If you have found out that they are an emergency then you may have no choice but to see them before lunch, but many admissions can wait for 15 minutes. Although it may be tempting to go and do smaller tasks first to get them over with, it delays more important tasks which does not show good prioritisation skills. You should never ask people not to bleep you, because a bleep is also used to let a doctor know about a deteriorating patient which is obviously important. You could potentially ask a nurse to triage a patient, but it seems more sensible to find out the information you need yourself over the phone, as it then does not use up the limited time of a nurse. Telling the staff that non-urgent tasks must wait until the end of the day is not necessarily true and could come across as obstructive and rude. Avoid upsetting nursing staff!

You are a junior doctor working an on-call shift. You are very busy and have just been asked to clerk a new admission and have not yet had a lunch break. You could be tied up with him for a while once he arrives and it has now passed 3pm. The nurses on the ward are bleeping you to come and rewrite a drug chart and write a discharge letter. You know that both of these tasks could wait until later when you are less busy, however the nursing staff are being very persistent. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
question_notes:
This question is about prioritising tasks. One of the most important things a doctor can do while on-call is to look after themselves. You are no good to patients if you are tired and hungry. By grabbing lunch quickly you will feel better and thus be better prepared to work. Clearly, clerking the patients is more immediately important than going to rewrite a drug chart, however it is still a task which will need doing. In general, nursing staff should understand that you have many people asking things of you during an on-call shift and a simple apology and estimate of a time you will be free to do it is sufficient to keep them happy. Finally, by finding out a bit about your patient before seeing them will enable you to better prioritise how quickly they will need seeing.

By clerking the patient before anything else, you risk delaying your already late lunch break by a lot longer. If you have found out that they are an emergency then you may have no choice but to see them before lunch, but many admissions can wait for 15 minutes. Although it may be tempting to go and do smaller tasks first to get them over with, it delays more important tasks which does not show good prioritisation skills. You should never ask people not to bleep you, because a bleep is also used to let a doctor know about a deteriorating patient which is obviously important. You could potentially ask a nurse to triage a patient, but it seems more sensible to find out the information you need yourself over the phone, as it then does not use up the limited time of a nurse. Telling the staff that non-urgent tasks must wait until the end of the day is not necessarily true and could come across as obstructive and rude. Avoid upsetting nursing staff!
title: GMC: Good medical practice - Communication, partnership and teamwork
body:
Communication, partnership and teamwork form one of the four domains listed in the Good Medical Practice. This domain focuses on the standards expected of doctors in areas such as communication and collaboration with patients and colleagues.

Effective communication
  • Listen to patients and answer any questions honestly
  • Ensure that information is delivered in a manner that can be understood. Identify and apply practical measures to overcome any communication and language barriers
  • Provide support and information to patients' relatives or carers in a considerate manner
  • Doctors on duty need to be easily reachable by their patients and colleagues for any advice or support

Partnership with patients
  • Empower patients with the information required for patients to make decisions with regards to their care. This includes information on the clinical conditions, treatment options and the relevant risks and uncertainties
  • Ensure that patients are aware of the progress of their care
  • The roles and responsibilities of each member of the team need to be made clear to the patients
  • Patient confidentiality needs to be maintained, even after the patient is deceased

Fair and respectful care of all patients
  • Respect patients' dignity and privacy
  • Respect any health, cultural and religious beliefs held by the patients, even if they do not agree with yours.

If you have a conscientious objection to a particular procedure e.g. abortion, you need to:
  • Inform the patient that they have the right to see another practitioner
  • Provide the necessary information and support towards the patient seeking another doctor. In doing so, refrain from expressing disapproval of the patient's lifestyle, choices or beliefs
  • Find another doctor to substitute you if it is not practical for the patient to arrange to see another doctor

Partnership with colleagues
  • Doctors are expected to work in a team in a manner that serves patients' best interest
  • It is important to respect the skills and contributions of every member of the team and be fair to every member of the team
  • Understand that your actions may affect others within and outside the team
  • It is your duty to complete any post that you have formally accepted as leaving the post assigned to you may compromise patient safety especially if this creates a gap in the medical rota
  • Unless the trust has a reasonable time to make adjustments, it is important that you work the hours required of your contract before leaving a job

Coordination of care between healthcare providers and between health and social care providers. This include
  • Providing all relevant information to all clinicians or social care providers involved in the care of the patients
  • Checking that a named doctor or team has taken over the care
  • Ensure that the clinician filling in for you or taking over the care is appropriately trained to provide safe care for the patient

The Good Medical Practice also made statements with regards to Doctors as teachers. It recommends that doctors support the training and teaching of junior staff members and medical students*. This includes
  • Ensuring adequate supervision
  • Writing honest feedback/references/appraisals on their competence, performance and conduct
  • Being a mentor
  • Supporting those who are struggling with their performance or health

*In all circumstances, patient safety needs to be prioritised
concept: Polite communication with colleagues can resolve most issues

options: Request that he showers prior to coming to surgery
Treat him medically for his cough and take no further action
Enquire 'how are you coping on your own' + refer social services if he agrees
Send him a formal warning with reference to recent Health and Safety legislation
Enquire 'how often do you wash' + offer to speak to his son
questions:
A 78-year-old man presents to surgery with a cough. He smells of urine and faeces and has an unkempt beard. He is currently living alone and has son who calls in once a month.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario looks at whether a Candidate is able to be sensitive.

Smelling of urine and faeces obviously indicates that a patient is not looking after himself properly. Asking a patient directly 'how often do you wash' may be construed as being rude and hence asking a more general question is preferable.

Just providing medical care for his cough addresses his physical and immediate needs but avoids longer term psychological and social problems.

Asking the patient to shower before coming into the surgery is unlikely to go down well. The patient may be unaware that he smells and could be deeply upset and offended by your comments.

Sending a formal warning is the worst option.

options: Explain that you will discuss the patient with them on the ward tomorrow
Inform them that it was inappropriate getting your number and never to ring it again
Advise the relative to speak to one of the nurses who is currently working on the ward
Tell the relative as much as you can remember about the patient
Hang up the phone
questions:
You are relaxing at home after a hard days work when you get a phone call on your personal mobile. It turns out to be a patients relative stating that they got your number from one of the other doctors on the ward and are ringing in regards to their relative who is based on the ward that you work on.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
C is the next best option. It passes on responsibility to a member of the team who is currently at work on the ward which is a more appropriate setting to speak.

A is the next best option. This politely deals with the situation in a way that does not break patient confidentiality. It also addresses the problem by offering the relatives another, more appropriate, time to meet and talk.

B and E are poor options. Although it was inappropriate they got your number, it is not the relatives who are at fault, it is the doctor who gave them your number and so being rude to the relatives is unfair. Hanging up the phone is deemed more rude and so is ranked lower than B.

D is the worst option. Firstly you can't be certain that you are in fact speaking with a relative. You are also unsure of whether the patient wishes their situation to be expressed to their family members and so you could be breaking patient confidentiality.
